citation.article-title: Rhodococcus roseus sp. nov., nom. rev.

p.s: Description of Rhodococcus roseus sp. nov., nom. rev. Tsukamura, Yano, Kudo, and Miyama.

Rhodococcus roseus (ro'se. us. L. adj. roseus, of rose; strains ATCC 271T and ATCC 4004 were previously placed in the taxon Bacterium mycoides roseum Grotenfelt 1889 [21]; the specific epithet was taken from this name)
The type strain is strain ATCC 271.

The description below is based on the type strain (among the distinguishing characteristics shown in Table 2, strain ATCC 4004 differs only in its ability to utilize trehalose as a sole carbon source).
Slightly acid-fast rods that are 3 to 7 μm long and 0.5 μm wide.
Mycelium is not formed.
Colonies are rough, dry, and pinkish in egg media and on modified Sauton agar medium (glutamate substituted for asparagine).
Grow occurs after 3 days.
Grow occurs at 28, 37, and 42°C but not at 45°C.
Resistant to 0.2% sodium para-aminosalicylate in Ogawa egg medium.

Resistant to the following compounds (tests conducted in Ogawa egg medium): hydroxylamine hydrochloride (0.25 mg/ml), sodium salicylate (0.5 mg/ml), paranitrobenzoic acid (0.5 mg/ml), and ethambutol (5 μg/ml).
Susceptible to the following compounds: rifampin (25 μg/ ml), 5-fluorouracil (20 μg/ml), mitomycin C (5 μg/ml), and hydroxylamine hydrochloride (0.5 mg/ml).
Tolerates 0.2% picric acid and 0.2% sodium nitrite in modified Sauton agar medium.
Arylsulfatase activity is negative after 14 days; niacin is not formed; para-aminosalicylate and salicylate are not degraded to catechol.
Tween 80 is not hydrolyzed after 14 days; catalase activity is semiquantitively positive (foam height, >45 mm).
α-Esterase and β-esterase activities are negative.
P-Galactosidase activity is negative.
Acid phosphatase activity is negative.
Nitrate is reduced to nitrite.
Acetamidase and urease activities are positive, but benzamidase, isonicotinamidase, nicotinamidase, pyrazinamidase, salicylamidase, allantoinase, and succinamidase activities are negative.
L-Glutamate, glucosamine, and acetamide are utilized as simultaneous nitrogen and carbon sources, but L-serine, benzamide , monoethanolamine , and trimethylene diamine are not.

Acetate, succinate, malate, pyruvate, benzoate, fumarate, ethanol, n-propanol, propylene glycol, 2,3-butylene glycol, n-butanol, and iso-butanol are utilized as sole sources of carbon in the presence of an ammoniacal nitrogen source.
Citrate, malonate, 1,3-butylene glycol, and 1,4- butylene glycol are not utilized as sole sources of carbon.
Glucose, fructose, sucrose, mannose, mannitol, and sorbitol are utilized as sole carbon sources, but L-galactose, L-arabinose, D-xylose, L-rhamnose, trehalose, and inositol are not.

Acetamide, urea, pyrazinamide, nicotinamide, and nitrate are utilized as sole nitrogen sources in the presence of a glycerol carbon source, but benzamide and nitrite are not utilized as sole nitrogen sources.
Only one α-mycolic acid spot is present on thin-layer chromatograms.
The numbers of carbon atoms present in the mycolic acids are 36,38,40,42,44, and 46 (center, 42 carbon atoms).
The number of double bonds in the mycolic acids is zero or one.
The number of carbon atoms in the α-unit is 14 or 16, and the number of carbon atoms in the β-unit is 20 to 32.
The G+C content of the DNA is 67.5 mol%.
The cell wall type is type IVA.
The menaquinone type is MK-8(H2) (>80%).
